targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "mem")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "disk")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.description:
🔧 Physical Cores
Each core has its own execution unit.

Can run one thread at full speed.

Ideal for parallel workloads like AI inference, video encoding, or compiling.

🧪 Logical Cores
Created by splitting a physical core into two threads.

Share resources (cache, execution units), so performance per thread is lower.

Useful for multitasking, I/O-bound workloads, or keeping the CPU busy while one thread stalls.

Think of physical cores as full-time workers, and logical cores as interns sharing desks — helpful, but not independent.

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "system")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "n_cpus")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Logical CPUs Number

panels.description:
Field Name	What It Tells You	Why It Matters
total	Total number of processes	Overall system load
running	Actively executing processes	Real-time demand
sleeping	Processes waiting for events	Normal for idle apps
blocked	Uninterruptible sleep (usually I/O wait)	Detects disk/network bottlenecks
idle	Truly idle processes	Helps distinguish from sleeping
stopped	Manually or system-stopped processes	Can indicate crashes or admin actions
zombies	Defunct processes not cleaned up	Signals poor process hygiene
total_threads	Total number of threads across all processes	Shows concurrency and thread pressure

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "processes")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "total" or r["_field"] == "running" or r["_field"] == "sleeping" or r["_field"] == "blocked" or r["_field"] == "idle" or r["_field"] == "stopped" or r["_field"] == "zombies" or r["_field"] == "total_threads")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Processes

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "mem")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "available" or r["_field"] == "used")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "mem")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "used_percent" or r["_field"] == "available_percent")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "mem")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "swap_free" or r["_field"] == "swap_total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.description:
usage_user	% of CPU time spent on user-level processes	Shows app and workload activity
usage_system	% of CPU time spent on kernel/system processes	Reveals OS and driver overhead

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "cpu")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "usage_system" or r["_field"] == "usage_user")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["cpu"] == "cpu-total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: System / User usage %

panels.description: The percentage of time the CPU isn’t doing anything — no user tasks, no system calls, just waiting.

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "cpu")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "usage_idle")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["cpu"] == "cpu-total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Usage Idle %

panels.description:
What it means: Time the CPU spends waiting for I/O operations to complete — usually disk or network.

Why it matters:

High iowait means your CPU is ready, but storage or network is dragging.

It’s a red flag for disk-bound workloads, slow SSDs, or overloaded buses.

Use it to:

Diagnose sluggishness in data-heavy tasks.

Validate SSD upgrades or disk optimizations.

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "cpu")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "usage_iowait")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["cpu"] == "cpu-total")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Usage IO Wait %

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "disk")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "used")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "disk")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "free")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "disk")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "used_percent")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: -5m)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "diskio")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "read_bytes" or r["_field"] == "write_bytes")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: 10s, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> difference()
  |> yield(name: "rate")

panels.description: Total time spent on I/O operations (ms)

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "diskio")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "io_time")
  |> derivative(unit: 1s, nonNegative: true)
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Disks IO Time

panels.description:
It’s the total time that I/O requests have waited on a block device, but with a twist: It’s weighted by the number of concurrent requests.

So if:

1 request waits for 100 ms → weighted_io_time = 100

10 requests each wait for 100 ms → weighted_io_time = 1000

It’s not just how long the disk was busy — it’s how intensely it was busy.

🔍 Why It Matters
High weighted_io_time means your disk is under heavy load — not just active, but stacked with queued requests

It’s a great indicator of I/O contention, especially on slow media like SD cards or USB drives

It complements io_time, which only tracks whether the disk was doing any I/O, not how many requests were stacked

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "diskio")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "weighted_io_time")
  |> derivative(unit: 1s, nonNegative: true)
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: Disks Weighted IO Time

panels.description:
It represents the number of I/O operations currently being processed by the disk at a given instant.

These include reads and writes that have been issued but not yet completed.

It’s a snapshot, not a cumulative counter — like peeking into the disk’s task queue.

targets.query:
from(bucket: "RaspberryPI")
  |> range(start: v.timeRangeStart, stop: v.timeRangeStop)
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_measurement"] == "diskio")
  |> filter(fn: (r) => r["_field"] == "iops_in_progress")
  |> aggregateWindow(every: v.windowPeriod, fn: mean, createEmpty: false)
  |> yield(name: "mean")

panels.title: iops in progress
